f5c95cc981bd.name: Startup Grind
f5c95cc981bd.shortDescription: The life, work, and tactics of entrepreneurs around the…

paragraphs.text: I’ve raised this question to management before (at a previous company) and got the “binders full of women,” explanation for trying to find women candidates to fill important executive level roles. I’ve even heard the, “we are going to hire the best candidate regardless of gender or race,” spiel.
CEOs that fit the description I mentioned above usually don’t think about it because the world is built for them.
paragraphs.name: e706

paragraphs.text: If a recruiter talks about “culture” in the second way, I push them for what that actually means. Because what it usually means is, “we’ve concocted an arbitrary set of attributes that define what a person who works here looks like.” Which means their focus is on creating a homogeneous workforce of people who look the same, come from the same socio-economic backgrounds, have the same type of education, are healthy, able-bodied and most likely attractive, are probably either white or asian, and between the age of 23–30. It does not leave room for people who are different or diverse. It doesn’t even leave room for people who are introverted or nerdy or have interests outside of what the organization deems cool.

Culture is not great when it is an undefined set of attributes used to determine whether or not someone is a “fit” for an organization. Or if it’s used in the same sentence as “snacks” and “ping pong” tables. Read: Jerks and the Start-ups they Ruin.
paragraphs.name: 1fe2

paragraphs.text:
ZERO women on the executive team.
Do I need to explain this one? Okay, I will. If there are no women in positions of leadership or the ones that are there fill traditionally female occupations like Human Resources or Customer Care (the ones that deal with the soft side of business), then it shows an organization that doesn’t support the growth of women or believe that women can fill important decision-making roles.
paragraphs.name: aef6

paragraphs.text:
You don’t interview with colleagues or people in more junior positions
This is a huge one for me. If the organization won’t let me interview my potential peers it shows me that they don’t value their opinions. They are planning on bringing someone in without the buy-in of the people who will be working directly for or with them. Or they are afraid of what they will say. Either way it a necessary part of the evaluation process and part of my due diligence.
paragraphs.name: 3c02

paragraphs.text: Culture is NOT great when it is an undefined set of attributes used to determine whether or not someone is a “fit” for an organization.
paragraphs.name: 1fe2

paragraphs.text: Which means their focus is on creating a homogeneous workforce of people who look the same, come from the same socio-economic backgrounds, have the same type of education, are healthy, able-bodied and most likely attractive, are probably either white or asian, and between the age of 23–30.
paragraphs.name: ab8f

d431460d3025.title: Don’t just look at the Exec Team.

paragraphs.text: Don’t just look at the Exec Team. Look at the % of Exec Team female DRs too. that’s pretty telling about leadership/pipeline. anyone can hire outside. it’s what they build inside (near the top) that tells the tale.
paragraphs.name: bec4

paragraphs.text: Every woman, seriously? Is hiring discrimination and bias already in the past, so every woman can afford to be choosy about job offers? Or can every woman afford living with no paycheck for months waiting for a prince… oops, a perfect team? Is a technical woman’s priority to get the best for her skills or should she sacrifice those opportunities…

b1074935f90d.title: Such a great read, and I can’t believe the accuracy.

paragraphs.text: Such a great read, and I can’t believe the accuracy. Some of things you’ve said match up with my experiences perfectly. Culture/ping pong — so true. No women on exec team — yes, and gives way to tolerating sexual harassment in the workplace.

I’m really glad we can bring up these issues and listen to each other sincerely. Thank you for packaging all of your thoughts up and sharing as well.

7f29c38407ef.title: Charli, Thanks so much for responding and for sharing with your class.

paragraphs.text: Charli, Thanks so much for responding and for sharing with your class. I’m definitely writing from my own Cisgendered/heterosexual perspective and you are right in reminding me to consider the trans/queer experience as well. I’m going to think about what you said and reflect. Thank you again for reaching out. I know how tiring it can be to construct consciousness in others but I really appreciate it.

Thanks for responding! It sounds like your company has an awesome culture, and one that they actively foster to make a healthy happy work environment. The “culture” I’m referring to in this article is not actual work-place culture. It’s usually ill-defined, not practiced, and used to exclude people during hiring or to write-off failures within the…
paragraphs.name: e582

eab2e8effd47.title: We have to invest our time and talents in companies that support women.

paragraphs.text: We have to invest our time and talents in companies that support women. Kind of how we shop with our dollar. The problem is we often don’t know that we are entering toxic work environments until we get there. That is meant to be the function of the “red flags” I shared. I believe they signal bad work environments. These companies should have to work…
